title: Epic: Sessions UI integration (daemon ↔ UI)
description:
Context:

- The daemon + CLI session system is implemented, but it is not surfaced in the GUI. Session badges exist in markdown, deep links exist, but there is no cohesive in-app session control.

Done means:

- Task list shows session status (Running/Waiting/Stopped).
- UI can Start/Continue/Stop sessions via a SessionClient.
- todos://session/<id> deep links route to the right UI action.

Verification:

- Manual: start a session from UI, detach/continue, see badge changes and attention indicators.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add a minimal integration test that proves Start/Stop updates markdown without clobber.
- Green: implement SessionClient + UI CTAs.
- Refactor: move daemon protocol glue behind a stable interface.

title: Sessions: Implement SessionClient (daemon RPC bridge)
description:
Context:

- The GUI currently relies on file watching to learn about session changes. We need a first-class client that can request actions (start/stop/continue/attach) and subscribe to daemon notifications.

Done means:

- Add a SessionClient module that can:
  - list sessions
  - start session for task
  - stop session
  - continue/attach
- Errors are mapped into user-visible messages (at least console + toast placeholder).

Verification:

- Manual: list sessions shows daemon state; start/stop works from UI.
- Automated: unit test that mocks the transport and verifies request/response shaping.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add a fake transport test with a few request/response cases.
- Green: implement minimal transport via a Tauri command that proxies to the daemon socket.
- Refactor: keep a single interface so we can swap transport (direct socket vs cli exec) if needed.

title: Sessions: Render session status + Start/Continue/Stop CTAs in TaskList
description:
Context:

- Session badges exist in markdown parsing, but the UI does not surface them as interactive controls.

Done means:

- Task rows show a compact session pill (Running/Waiting/Stopped).
- When appropriate, show buttons:
  - Start (no session)
  - Continue (Running/Waiting/Stopped)
  - Stop (Running/Waiting)
- Buttons call SessionClient, not direct markdown edits.

Verification:

- Manual: start session from UI and see state update; stop session updates.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add a component test with mocked SessionClient returning session states.
- Green: implement UI component + wiring.
- Refactor: extract SessionPill component and keep TaskList readable.

title: Sessions: Route todos://session/<id> deep links to Continue/Attach UX
description:
Context:

- The deep-link plugin receives todos:// URLs and handleLink dispatches a DOM event, but nothing consumes it to actually focus/continue a session.

Done means:

- Add a single routing layer that:
  - parses todos://session/<id>
  - focuses the app window
  - triggers a session action (open session list focused on id, or auto-continue)
- Remove the temporary DOM CustomEvent approach (or make it an internal-only bridge).

Verification:

- Manual: on macOS run: open "todos://session/42" and confirm the app focuses and routes to session 42.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add a unit test for deep link parsing + routing dispatch.
- Green: implement the router and wire to SessionClient.
- Refactor: keep all deep link handling in one module (no scattered listeners).

title: Sessions: Add a session list surface (running/waiting/stopped)
description:
Context:

- Without a dedicated surface, users can’t discover or manage sessions across tasks/projects, and attention events have nowhere to land.

Done means:

- Add a UI surface (panel/modal) listing sessions with status, task, project path.
- Selecting a session offers Continue/Stop actions.

Verification:

- Manual: open session list and manage at least one running + one stopped session.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: define types and a mock list rendering test.
- Green: implement minimal UI with SessionClient.listSessions().
- Refactor: fold into app navigation pattern (avoid ad-hoc modals everywhere).

title: Epic: Connected mode MVP (login + rooms + presence)
description:
Context:

- We want users to be able to log in and connect to each other. Today the app is entirely local-first with no identity, backend, or presence model.

Done means:

- Users can sign in/out (tokens stored securely).
- Users can create/join a room and see participants.
- Presence reflects planning/working/break + time remaining; task text sharing is opt-in.

Verification:

- Manual: two app instances join same room and see each other’s presence update on state changes.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: stub auth + room UI with fake in-memory provider and tests.
- Green: wire to a real backend/provider.
- Refactor: isolate provider-specific code and keep a small stable client API.

title: Connected: ADR - Pick auth/provider + backend approach
description:
Context:

- Connected mode needs identity + rooms. Provider choice impacts OAuth flow, token storage, and how quickly we can ship.

Done means:

- Write a short ADR in docs/ that answers:
  - Which provider (Supabase/Clerk/Firebase/custom) and why
  - Auth flow (PKCE via deep link vs device code)
  - Token storage approach (keychain/stronghold)
  - Realtime transport (provider channels vs WebSocket server)
- Identify what data is stored (presence only vs sync).

Verification:

- Review: ADR is readable, has explicit decision + consequences + follow-up tasks.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: list options + constraints.
- Green: pick one and record rationale.
- Refactor: reduce scope to presence-only MVP if needed.

title: Connected: Secure token storage (OS keychain)
description:
Context:

- We should not store auth tokens in ProjectStore.json. Tauri needs a Rust-side secret storage interface.

Done means:

- Add a Rust module that can set/get/delete secrets in OS keychain.
- Expose Tauri commands for AuthService to use (scoped, minimal surface).
- Include a way to clear all auth state on logout.

Verification:

- Manual: login stores token; restart app can read it; logout removes it.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: create a stub command that fails and a frontend test that expects failure.
- Green: implement keychain integration for macOS first.
- Refactor: add platform abstraction and fallback strategy for dev/test.

title: Connected: Account UI surface (login/logout + status)
description:
Context:

- Without a dedicated surface, auth flows become ad-hoc. We need a clear place for login, logout, and privacy toggles.

Done means:

- Add an Account/Connected section accessible from Planner (header button or settings panel).
- Shows: signed out vs signed in state, and a login/logout action.
- Includes placeholders for: share task text toggle, room membership.

Verification:

- Manual: open Account surface, sign in/out, see status update.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: stub AuthService with fake user; write a component test.
- Green: implement UI and wiring.
- Refactor: keep auth state in atoms/services rather than threading props.

title: Connected: Rooms UI (create/join) + fake in-memory provider
description:
Context:

- We want to build the UX and state model before committing to a backend. A fake provider lets us test flows end-to-end in dev/test.

Done means:

- Implement a Rooms UI:
  - create room → shows code/link
  - join room via code
  - participant list
- Backed by an in-memory provider that simulates presence updates.

Verification:

- Manual: open two windows (or two app instances) and see simulated users/presence.
- Automated: unit test the reducer/state machine for room membership + presence list.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: write tests for room join/leave + presence updates.
- Green: implement fake provider and UI.
- Refactor: define a stable interface so real backend can drop in.

title: Connected: Publish presence from local work state (rate-limited)
description:
Context:

- Presence must reflect planning/working/break and time remaining, without spamming the network or leaking task names by default.

Done means:

- Presence publisher subscribes to local events (state changes, coarse timer updates).
- Updates are rate-limited (e.g., every 15-30s max) and send minimal payload by default.
- Optional setting enables sharing current task text.

Verification:

- Manual: toggle between planning/working/break and verify other client updates within a few seconds.
- Automated: unit test rate-limiting behavior with TestClock.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add a test that asserts no more than N updates per minute.
- Green: implement publisher using EventBus.
- Refactor: keep privacy policy centralized (one module decides what can be shared).

title: Epic: Packaging hardening (bundle daemon/CLI, deep links, no test harness)
description:
Context:

- Release builds must consistently include the GUI + required sidecars (daemon/cli) and exclude dev/test-only artifacts. Today bundling can fail or accidentally include rn-test-harness.

Done means:

- tauri build bundles the right binaries/resources for release.
- Deep links work in release builds.
- CLI install/uninstall is predictable and documented.

Verification:

- Build a release DMG, install, run a smoke checklist (open project, start session, open deep link).

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add a scripted smoke test for the built app bundle.
- Green: fix bundle config/resources.
- Refactor: document packaging assumptions in docs/.

title: Packaging: Exclude rn-test-harness from release builds
description:
Context:

- We observed that release bundling can try to copy rn-test-harness and fail if it was never built, and it can end up inside the shipped app bundle.

Done means:

- Release builds do not depend on building rn-test-harness.
- rn-test-harness is not included in Right Now.app/Contents/MacOS.
- Test-harness builds still work via the tauri.test.conf.json config + --features test-harness.

Verification:

- Delete target/release/rn-test-harness and run: bun run tauri build
- Confirm the app bundles successfully and the resulting app does not contain rn-test-harness.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: reproduce current bundling failure on a clean target.
- Green: update bundle configuration/resources to include only intended sidecar binaries.
- Refactor: document the build matrix (release vs test harness).

title: Packaging: Bundle daemon + todo CLI intentionally
description:
Context:

- The app relies on sidecar binaries (right-now-daemon, todo, todo-shim). Bundling/paths need to be explicit so release builds behave like dev.

Done means:

- Tauri bundle includes the required binaries (daemon + CLI) and they are discoverable at runtime.
- CLI install/uninstall UX is documented and works for a default macOS setup.

Verification:

- Build DMG, install app, run the CLI install flow, and successfully start/continue/stop a session without dev tooling.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: write a smoke checklist that fails on a clean machine/profile.
- Green: update bundle resources + runtime path resolution.
- Refactor: centralize "where are my sidecars" logic in one module.

title: Packaging: Add scripted post-build smoke test
description:
Context:

- Packaging regressions are easy to miss (missing sidecar, deep links, wrong capabilities). We need a repeatable smoke test that runs after building.

Done means:

- A script exists (script/ or test/) that:
  - builds the app
  - installs/copies it into a temp location
  - launches it (or validates the bundle contents)
  - verifies sidecars exist and deep link scheme is configured

Verification:

- Run the smoke script locally and see it fail when a sidecar binary is missing.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: implement the script with at least one failing assertion today.
- Green: make it pass by fixing bundle config.
- Refactor: integrate into CI if/when we add CI builds.

title: Epic: Local v0.2 cohesive UX
description:
Context:

- The current app has strong core tech (markdown parsing, watcher, atomic writes) but lacks a cohesive first-run/project/task editing flow.

Done means:

- Welcome/project picker is first-class (recent projects, open/create).
- Tasks can be added/edited/reordered from the UI.
- Work/break state can persist across restarts.

Verification:

- Manual smoke: launch → open recent project → add/edit/reorder tasks → start/stop timer.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add failing E2E tests for each missing flow.
- Green: implement smallest UI + file edits to pass.
- Refactor: extract components/services to keep App.tsx small.

title: Welcome: Show recent projects and open directly
description:
Context:

- Current AppNoProject only shows an Open button and the app always drives a file dialog. This blocks fast repeat usage.

Done means:

- Welcome screen lists recent project paths from ProjectStore.
- Clicking a recent project loads it without showing a dialog.
- Still offer an "Open…" button to browse.

Verification:

- Manual: open two projects, relaunch, verify both show in recent list and open correctly.
- Automated: add a unit test for ProjectStore ordering + a component test for rendering recents (if we add RTL/Vitest) OR an E2E harness test that asserts recents UI.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: write a failing test that expects at least one recent project item.
- Green: implement minimal Welcome UI + load action.
- Refactor: extract Welcome into its own component and keep App.tsx thin.

title: Startup: Auto-load last active project without prompting
description:
Context:

- main.tsx currently calls projectManager.openProject(lastProject) which still opens a dialog. The intended UX is: if the last project still exists, just open it.

Done means:

- On launch, if ProjectStore.lastActiveProject exists and is readable, the app loads it directly via ProjectManager.loadProject().
- If it fails (missing file, permissions), fall back to Welcome/project picker with a clear error.

Verification:

- Manual: set lastActiveProject, relaunch, ensure it loads without dialog. Rename/delete file, relaunch, ensure fallback UI appears.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add an integration test for init path using the test harness (fixture project + stored lastActiveProject).
- Green: implement conditional direct load.
- Refactor: move startup logic into a small "bootstrap" module.

title: Project picker: Support opening a TODO.md file directly
description:
Context:

- ProjectManager.handleFolderOrFile supports file paths, but the dialog is configured as folder-only (directory: true).

Done means:

- The picker supports both "Open folder" and "Open file" paths (either separate buttons or a single dialog config that allows both if supported).
- Selecting a file loads it as the project file.

Verification:

- Manual: choose a TODO.md file; app loads it and watcher updates work.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add an E2E test in the harness that invokes ProjectManager.loadProject with an absolute file fixture.
- Green: implement UI/picker changes.
- Refactor: make the picker logic explicit (two actions) rather than implicit magic.

title: Tasks: Add new task from Planner
description:
Context:

- Today the app can only toggle completion; you must use an external editor to add tasks.

Done means:

- Planner view has an input (and keyboard shortcut) to add a new task.
- Added task is persisted to the TODO.md via ProjectManager.updateProject (read-fresh + atomic write).
- Markdown structure remains stable (headings/unrecognized content preserved).

Verification:

- Manual: add a task; confirm it appears and persists on disk.
- Unit: ProjectStateEditor update snapshot test ensures unrelated markdown is preserved.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add a failing unit test around inserting a new task into parsed markdown.
- Green: implement minimal UI + insertion logic.
- Refactor: extract "task insertion" into ProjectStateEditor helper.

title: Tasks: Edit task title/details in UI
description:
Context:

- Editing requires an external editor, which breaks the ‘Planner is enough’ story.

Done means:

- User can edit a task’s title (and details block, if present) from Planner.
- Save uses ProjectManager.updateProject (read-fresh + atomic write).
- Cancelling leaves file unchanged.

Verification:

- Manual: edit a task title and details; confirm markdown round-trips and external editor edits are preserved.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add a failing test demonstrating correct serialization for a task with details.
- Green: implement minimal inline edit UI.
- Refactor: centralize ‘find task to edit’ logic (avoid name-only identity if possible).

title: Tasks: Reorder tasks within a section
description:
Context:

- Reordering is planned in docs/TODO.md but not implemented. Markdown round-trip makes this non-trivial if we want to preserve unrecognized blocks.

Done means:

- User can move a task up/down (buttons is fine) within its section.
- Reorder preserves headings and non-task markdown blocks.

Verification:

- Unit: snapshot test with headings + unrecognized blocks proves reorder is stable.
- Manual: reorder tasks and confirm file structure remains readable.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: write a failing unit test for reorder in a mixed markdown structure.
- Green: implement reorder algorithm + UI affordance.
- Refactor: consider stable task IDs to avoid name collisions.

title: State: Persist work/break state + timestamps in frontmatter
description:
Context:

- WorkState/stateTransitions are ephemeral only. Restart loses timer state and breaks the ‘tracker as ambient metronome’ promise.

Done means:

- Frontmatter includes current state + transition timestamps (schema can change freely).
- On load, ProjectManager restores stateTransitions and workState from frontmatter when present.
- StateControls updates both in-memory and file state.

Verification:

- Manual: start work, quit, reopen, ensure timer resumes correctly.
- Unit: ProjectStateEditor parse/update round-trip tests for the new fields.

Red-Green-Refactor plan:

- Red: add a unit test asserting persisted timestamps survive update().
- Green: implement persistence wiring.
- Refactor: isolate durable vs ephemeral state clearly (types + docs).
